article.body: As Joe Biden leads President Donald Trump in polls ahead of Novemberâs election, analysts are already assessing how financial stocks could be affected by having the veteran Democratic politician in the Oval Office. âWe expect that financial stocks XLF, +0.11% Â will sell off later this summer if it looks like a Biden win is likely,â said KBW analyst Brian Gardner in a note on Sunday. âIn our opinion, investorsâ fear that the Elizabeth Warren wing of the Democratic Party could be in charge of financial regulation will weigh on financial stocks unless there is signal that a Biden administration will be led by centrists rather than progressives.â From the archives:All that a âPresident Warrenâ could change just by executive order Height Capital Markets analyst Edwin Groshans said that while the financial-services sector hasnât been called out recently in a big way by the former vice presidentâs White House campaign, there are risks for payday lenders such as Enova International Inc. ENVA, +1.85%, CURO Group Holdings Corp. CURO, +0.71%, Elevate Credit Inc. ELVT, +10.41% Â and FirstCash Inc. FCFS, -1.95%. He also sees potential challenges for student-lending and servicing companies such as Navient Corp. NAVI, +0.53%, SLM Corp. SLM, +0.11% Â and Nelnet Inc. NNI, -0.86% ; credit reporting agencies Equifax Inc. EFX, +1.53%, Experian PLC EXPN, +1.09% andÂ TransUnion TRU, +0.76% ; and auto lenders like Credit Acceptance Corp. CACC, -0.73%. Hereâs how the landscape could change for various parts of the financial industry. â¢ Payday lenders: Biden would have the authority to put in place a new Consumer Financial Protection Bureau director, and Heightâs Groshans expects the new boss would âroll back the proposed revisions to payday lending rule in a manner that eliminates the product completely,â saying it could be âterminated within three years.â â¢ Student loans: Biden is aiming to eliminate tuition fees for community colleges and job training programs tuition, as well as make public colleges and universities free for families earning under $125,000 a year. Such moves âwould reduce education loan originations, potentially materially, and servicing books and federal education loan investment portfolios would shrink as the current books amortize,â Groshans said in a note on Monday. â¢ Credit bureaus: Biden has proposed having the CFPB create a public competitor to the credit reporting agencies, and that âwould be negativeâ for Equifax, Experian and TransUnion, Groshans wrote. â¢ Other consumer-focused financial companies: âThe Biden campaign has promised to âreinvigorateâ the CFPB, so we expect a new wave of investigations will be aimed at student loan servicers, mortgage servicers, credit card companies, payday lenders, installment lenders, debt collectors, and credit-reporting agencies,â said KBWâs Gardner. â¢ Banks: âCommercial banks were among the industries that benefited the most from the Trump administrationâs regulatory agenda and banking regulation is likely to shift in a Biden administration, but maybe not as dramatically or as quickly as some investors think,â Gardner wrote. âThe composition of the Federal Reserve Board (the most consequential banking regulator) will remain mostly the same until 2022, when Chairman Jerome Powellâs term expires.â â¢ Investment banks and brokers: A Biden administration is likely to increase scrutiny of mergers and acquisitions by being more aggressive in antitrust reviews, which âcould be an overhang for the M&A advisers,â Gardner said. In addition, the Labor Department âmight scrap the latest proposal for a fiduciary rule and try to return to a version similar to what the Obama administration implemented in 2016.â â¢ Exchanges: âThe Biden administration has proposed a financial transaction tax (FTT) which we view as a negative for the exchanges,â Gardner said. âNormally, we would dismiss the idea of Congressâs passing an FTT, but in a COVID world where the government is searching for revenue to pay for the response to the pandemic, we cannot rule out the possibility that Congress will pass an FTT.â
